```
if 'extra' in config_param.keys():
```

```
    def test_args2body_vim_extra(self):
        auth_cred = {'username': sentinel.usrname1,
                     'password': sentinel.password1,
                     'user_domain_name': sentinel.user_domain.name,
                     'cert_verify': 'True'}
        config_param = {'project_name': sentinel.prj_name,
                        'project_domain_name': sentinel.prj_domain_name1,
                        'type': 'openstack',
                        'extra': {'area': 'area_A@region_A'}}

                        'type': 'openstack',

        vim_utils.args2body_vim(config_param.copy(), vim)
        self.assertEqual(expected_vim, vim)
```

I got the python-cinderclient-functional-py38 job to stop timing out ... which is great, but now both functional jobs are failing (before running any tests).

The weird thing is that the python-cinderclient-functional-py39 fails with "tox.tox_env.python.api.NoInterpreter: could not find python interpreter matching any of the specs py38", and the python-cinderclient-functional-py38 is failing with "tox.tox_env.python.api.NoInterpreter: could not find python interpreter matching any of the specs py39".

I checked the job defs in .zuul.yaml, and each one is calling the correct tox_envlist, and I have set the base_python (correctly!) in each tox testenv, even though that shouldn't be necessary (or at least, it didn't use to be).

Hi Kiran, 

Since the defaultadsite doesn't apply to Kerberos or LDAP, have you considered a different approach? Perhaps security service metadata? It kinda keeps the API simpler and allows configuratuon that we can pass on transparently.. 

One downside is that metadata updates are not taken back to the share driver - it might be something we can clarify in the documentation perhaps? Or have a reserved key that can only be set and not unset/modified? 

Sharing these thoughts in line with our current intention to allow metadata across all user facing resources: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/manila-specs/specs/yoga/metadata-for-share-resources.html. We've made some slow progress in this regard by adding metadata to snapshots recently..
Oh - so when you say its orthogonal to "server" -- would it mean it can be used by the driver in place of the server?
as far as security service are concerned, active directory can have either of one but not both. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila/+/855220/4/manila/api/v1/security_service.py#224

I had given a thought of having it as metadata before implementing this in our setup. This field is orthogonal to 'server' and carries same importance as that of 'server' field even-though its not applicable to other services like LDAP. E.g.
We have other field e.g. OU as part of service structure even-though its optional. 
Also, I believe there is less probability of adding new options under 'security service' in future as most are already in place. So if something comes up we can consider it under metadata in future.
I didn't understand It sounds more like a feature than a bug fix. If so, is there any spec ? How has it be accepted ? Is there any community discussion about this feature ?
Thanks Kiran. This feature is adding a new way of configuring the AD. How did you test it ? Have you coded some tempest test ? If not, is there any plan for working on it ? I think it would be nice.
defaultadsite was tested on our cluster. Sure, I will add tempest test.

Yes, this can be considered as feature, though not big enough to have spec. I see few other fields of security-service are merged as bug e.g OU.

>Is there any community discussion about this feature ?
Nothing as such. At this stage, this is specific to NetApp. https://kb.netapp.com/Advice_and_Troubleshooting/Data_Storage_Software/ONTAP_OS/What_is_Domain_Controller_Discovery
Thanks for working on this change and sorry for the time we took to review - Please take a look at the comments inline :)

Thank you for the enhancements. I was giving this some more thought and I really think we should follow the pattern that we have for core + driver changes, sorry :/

So what I'm asking is:
- Keep this change as a core change only (remove the NetApp drive modifications from this change)
- Propose a new change with the NetApp driver changes having a depends-on to this change.

If we keep the change like it is, we tend to seem that we are introducing features for a specific driver. It is also better for readability and future commits investigation if we keep things separate. We have other examples of people doing this in the past as well.

Other than this, I have nothing else to point out. Again, thank you for working on this change and for being responsive with the reviews.

manila/share/drivers/netapp/dataontap/cl.message: AIUI, these are property keys that are intended to be exposed to tenants. Including the netapp_ prefix in these keys would expose cloud implementation details to the tenant - which seems undesirable from a cloud provider scenario.

I see. Replaced the "netapp" by "set". I don't want to configure as "network_type" or simply "vlan", since there is a low possibility of a miss behavior where the user sets the metadata just to save extra information of the subnet and it ends up configuring those net resources
This needs some validation. Currently only 'vlan' is allowed, right?
The check is done by "_validate_network_type" right after this function call (see line 214). So we don't need to redo it here.

if metadata_mtu is not set and the one in the network_info is specified would we be ignoring the MTU set?
Shouldn't this be:
allocation['mtu'] = metadata.get(METADATA_MTU, network.get('mtu'))

I know network.get('mtu') might not return something too, but was just thinking if we are not ignoring the value for MTU when not set in metadata.

... and this scenario should go right into a unit test :)

Additionally I think we need input validation for METADATA_MTU, too. At least make sure it is an integer.
Makes sense, thanks for the explanation

Not setting the mtu means: I don't want to change its value. Retrieving the value from "network.get('mtu') means that the vlan is set manually but the mtu is set from network plugin. I think it is not desired. The goal of this feature is manually configure the network. If the operator wants to manually set the vlan, he/she should set the mtu too manually. If he/she does not set it, it means that they want to keep as the default one. This behavior will be documented (release note and netapp documentation).


About the MTU integer check, I agree. Added to next patchset with its UT.

octavia/controller/worker/v2/flows/liste.message:
hmm, I'm wondering if we should really unregister the secret on revert.
After the revert, the listener (or the pool) still exists in the DB (in ERROR) with a ref to the secret.

It means that:
* the user can delete the secret (it is unregistered)
* an admin can trigger a potentially successful failover of the LB but the secret in the ref will be missing
Yeah, this is a good catch. The consumer is registered in the API tier when we create the provider driver data, so removing it here would be bogus.

This actually generates a new, random IQN, and this should only be done when the .initiator_reset sentinel file is missing. The purpose of the sentinel file is to ensure the IQN is reset once, and only once.

Background: when overcloud nodes are deployed from a common overcloud image, they are all "born" with the exact same IQN (which is a problem). The IQN must be reset on each node (but only reset once!) to ensure all overcloud nodes have a unique IQN.

is there a case where we delete and update metadata in the same request? if not, in case of delete we could possibly return after we execute everything inside this condition. Is there something I'm missing?

The code here is using the same approach as the snapshot metadata to keep compatibility among metadata resources: see function "_share_snapshot_metadata_update". Given that the functions are API for accessing the db, they are trying to deliver the possibility of cleaning up before the update.  However, both share snapshots and share subnets functions are not using that possibility.

Returning after the delete means that this function is either deleing or updating. That's is not the goal here. The idea of this function is to be called when you want to update metadata cleaning the metadata before it. The idea is not to delete or update. For deleting without an update there is the function "share_network_subnet_metadata_delete".

What I mean is: we can remove the possibility of cleaning before updating, since calls are not using this possibility. The downside is that this methods are called agnosticly by metadata helper, so we should to remove this behavior from all metadata db APIs. I wouldn't like to change other metadata resources.

manila/policies/share_network_subnet.py.message: This should follow wallaby here and below iirc :)
Can I remove the deprecation or set it to Wallaby ?
Isn't it possible to just not add those deprecated rules at all?

It needs to be "ANTELOPE" not ZED or wallaby, since these policies are being introduced in the Antelope release.

To answer the second question on why these are even needed:

Currently, all manila RBAC policies are undergoing a prolonged change [3] to support two new concepts: the use of "scope" on user accounts, and the default "reader" role from Keystone. This extended duration deprecation is painful, but done so as to not break deployments. The "new" RBAC rules require the use of "scope" in existing user accounts, and allow for a "reader" role to be attached to users. While the latter is an easy transition, requiring scope may break existing user accounts created on existing clouds. 

Across the community, we had a goal of supporting system scope in all the projects and manila policies experimented with this change in Wallaby. However, during subsequent PTGs and ops meetups, we discovered that operators didn't like the "system" scope; they preferred that we implement an "admin" role consistently across services and that the "admin" role be allowed cross tenant super user privileges as it currently is. So, we made another change in Zed removing support for "system" scoped users.

In Antelope, nova and glance [1][2] are switching the new rules to apply by default. In Bobcat, manila will do the same. We will be dropping all these deprecated rules in the "C" (2024.1) release. 

Until the removal, introducing new policies will require us to support both scoped and unscoped users as well as existing roles (just "member" and "admin" by default) and new roles ("member", "admin" and "reader") - This is why we have the deprecations piling up. One could argue that this makes no sense for net _new_ APIs- however, having these deprecated rules will allow an existing cloud to separate concerns and implement the RBAC transition separately from their need to use the new features.


[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/866218
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance/+/873372
[3] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/dell_em.message: OK, these are missing the 'force_vol_edit' field.  (I thought you were missing a test case.)

Does your code do some pre-processing on the extra_specs somewhere?  Because if these are just "normal" extra_specs, shouldn't this be a string value (e.g., "<is> True")?  (And what happens if it's set to "<is> False"?)

Yes, please look at this https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/746758
Regarding "<is> False" is answered in another comment.
You also need to check when force_flag=False, because it's counterintuitive that a caller passes force_flag=False and the result is still going to be 'true' based on the extra_specs.

Right, but when you look at this from the point of view of someone calling the function, they have 3 options:

1. pass force_flag=True -> expect that force will be used
2. don't pass anything -> expect that the extra_specs flag will determine whether force is used
3. pass force_flag=False -> this one is ambiguous ... someone might think this overrides the extra_spec

The problem with #3 is that someone might refactor the function at some point and make the passed value override the extra_spec.  But if you have a test for this, their refactor will break the unit test and they'll realize that something is wrong.  Also, it serves as documentation for how you expect the function to behave.  So I really think you should add it.
The test before runs with the default value of the force_flag=False

I submit my candidacy for Zun PTL. I would suggest @zhangchi to contribute to the Zun project and gain some understanding of the code base first. Zun definitely welcomes contributions from new contributors.

The current charter[1] states "Any APC can propose their candidacy for the corresponding project PTL election".  An APC is defined[2]:

  Voters for a given project’s PTL election are the Active Project Contributors (“APC”), which are a subset of the Foundation Individual Members. Individual Members who committed a change to a repository of a project over the last two 6-month release cycles are considered APC for that project team.

So as of now we can not accept this candidacy.  Should the Zun project end the election without a PTL the TC may accept this as part of the leaderless project process[3].

we chatted about this so this should be a set of host cpu ids
not a guest object

alternitivly you can pass the instance numa toplogy blob.

What will happen after a reconfiguration of nova from strategy=='cpu_state' to startegy='governor' ? I think in that case there can be cpus that are offline but we won't try to online them here any more. 

Also the revers direction can be interesting too. I.e. we set a low governor to a cpu, then nova was reconfigured to cpu_state and therefore we online the cpu here but keep the low governor on it.
this is now resovelved with the check in init host

when you write up the doc please note this. This means if cpu_power_management_strategy == governor is used then we don't allow any manually offlined CPUs even if they are not mentioned in cpu_shared|dedicate_set. This case nova a bit oversteps its boundaries as it puts constraints to pcpu cores that are never used by nova.

in the docs we should also note that core 0 generaly cannot be offlined and its
considerd bad pratice to include it in cpu_dedicated_set in general.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
here and elsewhere you shoudl be passing instance.numa_toplogy.cpu_pinning

that is the set of host cpus used by the guest

it is the vlaues of cpu_pinning_raw

cpu_pinning_raw is a map of the qemu cpu id to host cpus.

InstanceNUMACell(cpu_pinning_raw={0=0,1=1,2=2,3=3,4=6},cpu_policy='dedicated',cpu_thread_policy='prefer',cpu_topology=<?>,cpuset=set([]),cpuset_reserved=None,id=0,memory=2048,pagesize=None,pcpuset=set([0,1,2,3,4]))

to find what corea a logical guest core is pinned too you index the cpu_pinning_raw dictionary witht teh vm core id.

so n the exampel above the first vm core is pinned to host core 0 and the 5th vm core is pinned to host core 6

instance.numa_toplogy.cpu_pinning is the same as cpu_pinning_raw.values()

I have added more robust test results to the commit message.  Since the admin heartbeating will inevitably fail for seconds at at time in the process of re-configuring new subnetting information at runtime (on both controllers), currently only an alarm will be raised on heartbeat failure.  I have implemented the mechanism of allowing the admin-interface be de-provisioned (not-in-use), and then provisioned (unknown state - at which point it will transition back to enabled if all state requirements are met).  I think the intention should be that if an admin interface completely fails, that the inactive controller takes over if it meets the requirements for failover.

service-mgmt/sm-db/database/create_sm_db.message: do we want to default provision the admin-interface?

No.  The admin network (and thus interface) is optional, so we can defer provisioning until it's actually created.  I discovered after the initial patch set that SM has an existing CMD syntax for provisioning a service domain interface:  ie. sm-provision service-domain-interface controller admin-interface.  Because of this, I have changed the implementation a bit to leverage this facility, with an added '--apply' flag to make it mirror the implementation of the service configuration.  Therefore, for both re-config of the admin-ip and admin-interface parameters, puppet will take care of 1. deprovisioning the service/interface 2. reconfiguring (updating the runtime db) and 3. re-provisioning the service.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: How does the new fixed version work when an admin takes an external snapshot, renames it, manages it, and then reverts to the snapshot? don't we unexpectedly lose reference to the snapshot there too? i wonder if you can add some logic to the "revert-to-snapshot" method to reconcile the snapshot?

You are right. The issue will still happen if the renames occurred externally to Manila. Actually, the bug can be even worse. All snapshots are returned back to the name when reverting, not only the one that reverted. Example:


1. Take snap1
2. Take snap2
3. Rename snap1 -> my_snap1
4. Rename snap2 -> my_snap2
5. Manage my_snap1
6. Manage my_snap2
7. Revert to my_snap2

As result, the provider location of both snaps will be as "my_snap1" and "my_snap2", but the actual name is "snap1" and "snap2".

The revert process can change the name of several snapshots, not only the one that is was used to revert.

another point, how can manila know the original name  to rename back ? In the example, how could the manila know the original snap name ("snap1" and "snap2") ?

Hmmm, maybe its not worth optimizing this; but rather call this out as a known issue; we don't provide a way to rename the provider_location field on a snapshot if this happens though - so the general advice would be to be mindful of unnecessary reference name changes on the backend and consider that the manila driver uses the original name to locate snapshots..

nova/virt/libvirt/host.py.message: You should perhaps indicate what you mention in the comment line 750 here in the docstring.
I don't like that we do this in a function that is named `get_online_cpus` this can be a major confusion for the caller as we return offline cpus too

An alternative would be to push the cpu_power_management logic one level higher in the call stack. get_online_cpus() is called from 3 places in non-test code:
* _get_emulatorpin_cpuset
* _get_pcpu_available
* _get_vcpu_available 

As far as I understand cpu_power_management only affects dedicated cpus so I think _get_emulatorpin_cpuset and _get_vcpu_available is not affected. So the only remaining place affected is _get_pcpu_available. I think that is a fairly good place to implement the addition of offline cpus to the online ones if cpu_power_management is enabled. Sure it needs another helper to call self.get_connection().getCPUMap() again but that still less of a code than the rename above.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L7740-L7749

[Just randomly chiming in]

Renaming could be done, but I agree; it's confusing.

Maybe its best to do it in one go right away and rename it to something like: get_cpu_power_status() or get_cpu_status()
ya i would be ok with gibi’s suggestion.

I pretty much like gibi's suggestion, which is neat : we only compare online cpus against the dedicated set in _get_pcpu_available(), while _get_emulatorpin_cpuset() checks the online state of shared CPUs (which we don't care in this series) and while _get_vcpu_available() only uses the online CPUs *if* we don't have a cpu dedicated set.

  net.ipv4.tcp_keepalive_intvl = 75
  net.ipv4.tcp_keepalive_probes = 9
  net.ipv4.tcp_keepalive_time = 7200

To give us an additional connectivity check I wonder if making these smaller then the client_idle setting could allow us drop disconnected connections, and use the client_idle as the big hammer if things are just taking too long. Something like (off the top of my head):

  keep_idle = 5
  keep_cnt = 3
  keep_interval = 2

And see what hit the empty packets every few seconds gives us in regards to performance.

Might have a play with it.

The suggestion to run a collect and look at a file within the collect tarball, is not a "repair action". 

A proper repair action would depend on the error and be something like, "Manually restart Ceph processes and check the state of the Ceph cluster with 'ceph -s'
Waiting for the test plan change requested by John, before bumping up the vote

So the main problem I have with this is that this product should be highly available, self-healing, and fault tolerant. Meaning, that I'd prefer less end-user "hacking" by telling them try these 10 things. I actually WANT bugs opened when the system is in a bad/weird state so that we can diagnose problems an improve reliability.

If we feel strongly that we don't provide enough information when alarms arise, then we should update the alarm message to refer to the troubleshoot docs before contacting next-level support, enhance the product documentation around trouble shooting, and specifically stress the importance of running collect and opening bugs.

Is that something we want to start doing ?
That's not a repair action.

Yeah I agree with Eric & Bob that putting 'run collect' in proposed repair action is not good.  'Collect' is something we typically do for debugging software errors.

The Proposed repair action should be a specific action or command to resolve the issue.  If the repair action is unknown and requires some more general troubleshooting, we probably need to refer to a troubleshooting section in the starlingx ceph customer documentation.

I am giving this a lot of thought and decided to remove my vote for now.

There are some big concerns with this change, and we are way past feature freeze:
The possible problems with the quota allocation that Goutham mentioned and also the concerns with the Ceph driver, which is receiving this update based on the way the driver operates.

The unit test coverage on the APIs looks okay, but we do not have a change for tempest including new test scenarios. I have tested some basic scenarios and they worked just fine, but without the tempest tests (that should've been submitted alongside this feature considering the Feature Proposal Freeze deadline [1]), we cannot test much with the Ceph driver for example and we risk merging something that could not receive a backport in the future.

I really like this feature, but it feels like we are rushing it and with that comes lots of risks.

I would like to hear more thoughts on this, and possibly here the safest option for Manila, is to defer this merge to the A cycle, so we will be able to have more time to review and tempest tests implemented to back us up.

[1] https://releases.openstack.org/zed/schedule.html#z-manila-fpfreeze

why continue? we want to invoke "transfer_accept" for the correct share instance or probably _every_ share instance? I'm a bit confused, so let me explain what i'm thinking:

you'll have more than one share instance in case of replicated shares. There you have three scenarios:

1) "Writable" replication
- Each share instance has its own access rule mappings, and the driver will need calls per share instance to delete all the rules (if "clear_rules=True and there are any access rules)
- call the driver to accept transfer with any of the instances (all of them will have replica_state="active")
2) "Readable" replication
- Each share instance has its own access rule mappings, the driver will need calls per share instance to delete all the rules (if clear_rules=True and there are any access rules)
- call the driver to accept transfer with the share instance that has its replica_state="active" 
3) "DR" replication
- Only the instance with replica_state="active" will have access rule state mappings, and so we need to call the driver with the specific instance to delete all the rules (if clear_rules=True and there are any access rules) 
- call the driver to accept transfer with the instance with replica_state="active"

Carloss and I brainstormed this a bit more and realized my suggestion above isn't sufficient.

For a given active/readable replica, we need to send a request to the correct host to deal with the access rules - currently the code tries to do that with the host of the share (which is really the host of the representative instance) and this won't work with the way replication is designed.  

I think we need to redesign how shares with multiple instances can be transferred safely mainly around the access rules concern. 

One way could be that we gather the instances that need access rule changes and send RPC requests to the specific backends out of the API itself and wait before accepting the transfer of the share itself; or we could initiate the RPCs from the share manager too (Carlos pointed me to other places where we do this). I'd be interested to hear your thought on how to approach this. 

Whatever approach we pick, i think it's wise to get this tested with a backend like ZFSOnLinux or NetApp so we don't miss anything. 

Since we're running too close to feature freeze, would it be wise to disallow transferring multiple shares with instances (replicated shares) right now... and have that functionality come in a follow up patch?

I can add this to the PTG for us to put our heads together and redesign.

https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/manila-bobcat-ptg-planning

WDYT?

It still feels that we are some logic that should be added to the driver into the share manager.

I was thinking of this and I had one idea:

- We keep the condition from line 3591
- right after line 3597, we set the access_rules variable to an empty list [], as we know if everything went right, access rules should be gone by now.
- We remove the condition from line 3604 and send the request to the driver for transfer_accept even if the driver does not have something to do.

That way we would be allowing other drivers that might benefit from this feature to do not need to modify any behavior in the manager in the future, as the share manager would not be verifying logic that drivers should be checking on particularities of its implementations and structure.

In case of the current cephfs driver: nothing will need to be modified as we will send an empty list of access rules and it is doing things completely relying on having access rules or not.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I think we need a rethink.

* I don't think we can expose the HAProxy admin socket unauthenticated via TCP

* openstack-ansible suggests they use separate certs for each load balancer. That would avoid the sync, and greatly simplify the design. We could also use a unix admin socket. See https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ansible/latest/user/security/ssl-certificates.html#certbot-certificates and https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-haproxy_server

* we need to store the certs on disk, as well as dynamically updating HAProxy. This would be a lot easier if we only had to update the local HAproxy

* the bootstrapping process seems clumsy, and it concerns me that a reconfigure doesn't work. A colleague suggested using certbot standalone mode to bootstrap when we don't have certificates.That could be fiddly, but either way, I'd like to see a clean, documented way to bootstrap this (that ensures we don't overwrite the LE certs with our own self-signed ones). It might involve getting HAProxy running first to bootstrap LE, then running another deploy with everything else.

* the internal API support doesn't seem that useful to me, and if we're going to iterate the design then it might be easier to remove it

Overall, I'd like to see a written plan for the approach, that a few people can agree on - we should have enough context at this point to agree on a design.
LGTM, but need to add task to check existence of the kolla_internal_fqdn and kolla_external_fqdn because role can be enabled but FQDNs didn't useв - in this case we should notify user and fail.

My review is pending but I already have one comment to share - letsencrypt-acme should be renamed everywhere to something like letsencrypt-webserver as this is a webserver for letenscrypt functionality and not an ACME server. The current wording is confusing.

What we need is to rewire haproxy so that it uses a volume dedicated to containing the letsencrypt key(s) and certificate(s). If letsencrypt is used (true), then the haproxy container should start with this volume and copy the fallback key and cert from /etc if the volume is empty. This way we ensure that we always have the fallback code, do not overwrite the new key and can update it independently.

only one is run per script execution.
Is this fixed by pebble? Any reason why we can't set it to the same value as kolla_external_fqdn and kolla_internal_fqdn?

ansible/roles/letsencrypt/templates/star.message: certbot runs every time the container starts?
Yes - the script that either creates the cert or checks for renewal is executed
I still don't really get why we need this one.
What happens in a multinode scenario? Will all certbot containers try to generate certificates? Could that cause a problem?

This is not a problem. All nodes will attempt to generate certificate. However, only the certbot running on the node which the fqdn is directing towards will be successful, since the acme server on that node will return the required token. The other nodes will not succeed.
We want to run certbot immediately after deployment to generate the certificate. The Cron job will run periodically (every 12 hrs) to renew the certs.

ansible/roles/letsencrypt/templates/upda.message:
From https://www.haproxy.com/blog/dynamic-ssl-certificate-storage-in-haproxy/:

Although updating a certificate in memory means you don’t need to reload HAProxy, it’s a good idea to store the file on the HAProxy server so that when you do perform a restart or reload, HAProxy will pick up the new file at startup, rather than reverting back to a stale version that’s still on disk. There are a number of ways to do this, such as by using Rsync, SCP, or SFTP to transfer the files to the remote HAProxy server. For example, you could use this one-line SCP command to do it:

scp new_certificate.pem username@172.25.0.10:/etc/haproxy/certs/site.pem
Would we be better off putting these commands in a script that we can execute in one connection? Could also more easily lock down the SSH config potentially.
why not creating volume for LE keys and mount it on images which needs cert?

Since lets encrypt keys are generated after deployment, and then refreshed periodically after expiration, the keys would still be required to be transferred from a single HA node to all other replicated HA nodes. Maybe I don't fully understand the question. Thanks.

ansible/roles/loadbalancer/templates/hap.message: Why do we need to show the cert?
We don't, but it's good if you are debug tracing the certificate update, especially during functional test. I can remove it if requested.
Seems like this will end badly once LE has done a rotation.

Exposing an unauthenticated admin socket on the internal API network is dangerous. It even says so in the haproxy docs!

What is it required for?

The admin socket needs to be exposed to be able to dynamically update the certificate. It is how to enable the HAProxy Runtime API. I tried it at both the operator and user level, but that did not provide enough permissions.

https://www.haproxy.com/blog/dynamic-ssl-certificate-storage-in-haproxy/

I have updated this to be configured only when LE is enabled.
I'm afraid that's a blocker for me. Exposing the runtime socket unauthenticated via TCP gives anyone with access to that network the ability to control HAProxy - change certs, backends etc.

We are copying the original certificate to letsencrypt volume, and setting the correct permissions. This copied certificate on the lets encrypt volume will ultimately be replaced with the LE cert (though it is backed up). 

This is done to preserve the original self signed cert in the case that the deployer wants to revert to the original deployed openstack state, and to isolate the docker volume where disk changes can occur.

It will cause deployment to fail if it doesn't happen as the last role - or else subsequent roles will fail with with "unable to get local issuer certificate" when using pebble.
Should the role run just after haproxy?
No, since the default cacert used during deployment becomes incorrect after letsencrypt deployment. It should be last. This will break deployment when using pebble, and the cacert changes.
Going back to this, you're saying that the deployment will be broken after letsencrypt runs? Could we add both CA certs to the trust store?
hmm. I find it a shame we have to use these bootstrap certificates. I thought LE was supposed to make it easy? Perhaps it's something we can iterate on later.

This was part of the spec - First bootstrap the self signed certificates, then replace with trusted certificates.

We could certainly iterate on us.

When using a real valid SSL certificate for the domain, deployment should not be broken. When using a certificate from pebble, it will be broken, since the deployment node would need access to pebble to gather the CA certs. I believe the only way around this is to have deployment itself run certbot instead of generating certs.

We need the self signed CA for backend TLS to work. HAProxy needs the CA cert for the SSL handshake.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Note, this appears to keep a commit but without changes. If you run `git show HEAD` after this operation you have a commit message with no diff. This is different than the git merge case which simply exits 0 and reports `Already up to date.`

For many users this might be fine. But if you use git repo state to calculate versioning for example this could be a problem.

A better solution with fewer side effects may be to avoid merging anything in the case of change-merged/ref-updated events and simply checkout the state of the system at that point in time? I haven't dug in to see what would be involved in doing that, but would avoid problematic side effects in the git tree.

Here's an experiment I'd like you to run to collect information to help us decide how to proceed:

Propose a change to gerrit in a cherry-pick repo which is identical to a commit already in the branch.  Does that work?  If so, submit it.   Does that work?   What does the resulting tree look like?

That's the behavior we need to mimic, because the pre-merge behavior should match Gerrit exactly.  If we need to alter the behavior for a post-merge change-based pipeline, then we may need to add a pipeline option, or start paying attention to the 'merged' flag on the change.

OK, so `--keep-redundant-commit` keeps an extra commit that we're not actually interested in having. I think maybe `--allow-empty` would be the better option then:

> Commits which are made empty due to a previous commit are dropped. To force the inclusion of those commits use --keep-redundant-commits.

`git cherry-pick --allow-empty` is unfortunately insufficient because it only applies to commits that are _initially_ empty (that is, the commit you are cherry-picking from is empty). There is no option to tell git to skip cherry-picking a commit that does nothing; you can either apply the empty commit with `--keep-redundant-commit` or have `git cherry-pick` fail so you can inspect the results.

The other option would be to use `--keep-redundant-commit` and then manually inspect if the commit is empty after applying and hard reset back if so.


Or filter based on the event, but I don't see any other events doing that sort of thing.

Proposing a change identical to a commit in the branch works (provided it has a unique Change-Id footer in the commit message, so the commit hash _is_ different in my experiment).

As for submitting, it depends on the `submit.rejectEmptyCommit` project setting in Gerrit. If `submit.rejectEmptyCommit = True`, you get an error when you submit:

> Could not perform action: Failed to submit 1 change due to the following problems:
> Change 4184: Change could not be merged because the commit is empty. Project policy requires all commits to contain modifications to at least one file.

If `submit.rejectEmptyCommit = False`, the submit succeeds, and the change is marked as merged by Gerrit, but no extra commit appears in the git log. I believe this matches the `--allow-empty` option to git cherry-pick.

Tested on Gerrit 3.6.1.

how does this work? We've a requirement that is constrained to be only installed if python version is less than 3.10

importlib_resources>=3.2.1;python_version<'3.10' # Apache-2.0

That said, neither cinder nor os-brick has importlib_resources as a dependency, so I'm not sure where it's coming from.  'pip freeze' shows that it's in 5.8 and 5.9 but not in py3.10:

  [tox-4-ready] wha'ppen? .tox/py38/bin/pip freeze | grep importlib
  importlib-metadata==5.0.0

  [tox-4-ready] wha'ppen? .tox/py39/bin/pip freeze | grep importlib

  importlib-resources==5.10.1
  [tox-4-ready] wha'ppen? .tox/py310/bin/pip freeze | grep importlib
  importlib-metadata==5.0.0

Thanks for the note, Rodolfo.  There was an issue in tox where basepython=python3 set in [testenv] would cause the system python3 to be used for any of the -pyXX environments instead of the requested python.  I think that's been fixed, but now there's an open issue where basepython=python3 doesn't work with functional-pyXX environments: https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/2838

I propose to wait for ^^ to be fixed and released, and then do a recheck on this patch (and look to make sure that each job is using the correct python version!).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This is a very complete patch. Nice work. Couple of nits but nothing a quick respin won't be able to address. I'm obliged to ask the same question I always ask when I see things like this though: does this really need to be configurable? Is there any reason someone would *opt out* of image compression and another user would *opt in*? If not, couldn't we set opinionated defaults.

As an aside, RHEL 9 dropped support for the SPICE display protocol [1]. While it's still supported in upstream libvirt and (presumably) other distros like Ubuntu or SLES, I'm not sure this is the best horse to back long-term.

[1] https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/9/html/considerations_in_adopting_rhel_9/assembly_virtualization_considerations-in-adopting-rhel-9#ref_changes-to-spice_assembly_virtualization

Thanks for your review. I corrected all the marked nits and rebased the patch.

I answered your question regarding the need for those configuration knobs in the corresponding spec to this implementation, which will be discussed in the team meeting tomorrow.


> As an aside, RHEL 9 dropped support for the SPICE display protocol [1]. While it's still supported in upstream libvirt and (presumably) other distros like Ubuntu or SLES, I'm not sure this is the best horse to back long-term.

I know that RedHat abandoned SPICE and dropped it in the latest RHEL release. I also talked to Radosław as part of a private conversation where we speculated about the reasons regarding this decision. I only found a short statement from a RedHat employee [2]. Personally, I do not understand RedHat's decision. SPICE provides convenient interaction features that cannot be replaced by any other open-source solution yet, as described in your cited changelog [1]. Why should the community take a technical step backwards?

Other reasons and problems mentioned in [2] can be easily solved by some minor changes, for example replace the codec for video encoding to an free-licensed codec (e.g. VP8, VP9), ...

[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2030592#c4

I've added Sean and Sylvain as reviewers so that they will be informed about my prototype of the highly-discussed SPICE compression support. You can take a peek behind the scenes if that might be needed tomorrow when we discuss the spec in the weekly team meeting.

A (hopefully last) question regarding the workflow: Is there any keyword (or need) to reference a spec in the commit message as part of a patch?

After the tox issue in the check pipeline has been resolved, the check for this code change succeeds.

Now, this patch is rebased and ready for a final review.

Indeed, was very well self-contained and correctly written.

I enjoyed reviewing it. Many thanks for the hard work.

Apologies in advance for the long comments ... this issue has turned out to be more complicated than I thought.

I did some more local testing with this because I kept thinking about the block_device_mapping DB table records and eventually found a problem ...

It's unfortunately not going to be enough to only exclude the swap BDM after the resize. Because the XML is regenerated in part from the BDM records in the DB, if these are not kept in sync with the current instance flavor, it can cause the libvirt driver to fail when generating the XML and then the instance goes into ERROR state and is unusable.

To reproduce the ERROR:

1. Boot an instance with swap
2. Resize to flavor with no swap and confirm resize
3. Hard reboot the instance (openstack server reboot --hard <instance>)
4. Instance is now in ERROR state and it is not running

This ^ scenario is IMHO worse than the current behavior because with the current behavior the user gets an ERROR immediately as opposed to a potentially long time later when the user reboots or stop/starts the instance. For that reason, I think we need to handle the BDM DB records in this patch. I can help with this if you prefer as this problem seems keep getting bigger.

My -1 this time is because IMHO the potential long delay to an instance in ERROR state is a worse user experience than having it fail immediately.

I will add some inline comments with my thoughts.

The change itself looks good but it's non-ideal that the func tests don't fail without the fix in place. Currently whether we fix the bug or not, these tests will pass.

It may be the case that there isn't a way to reproduce the behavior in the func test environment. I think it would be worthwhile to look into it a little. I'm thinking about nova/tests/functional/libvirt/. I will check that later to see if anything jumps out.

I did remember though that you have a good tempest test proposed for this [1], so it's good that it's not critical that we have func tests that repro the bug. I'm just not sure how much value the currently proposed tests bring.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/858885

i agree that is worse.

also agree we need to keep the db in sync correcly.

To summarize my -1, I think we need to:

1) Remove the changes to the DefaultFlavorsFixture and instead create the flavors we need in the tests themselves. Doing this will eliminate all of the API samples changes and objects test changes

2) Add verification of DB BDM records -- we want tests that will fail without the bug fix and pass with the bug fix

3) Do the BDM update/sync logic in _finish_resize instead of _confirm_resize in order to keep consistency between the instance XML and the BDMs

4) Add rollback logic to revert resize to undo any BDM record updates we may have made earlier in _finish_resize

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
So far what I have tried and seems to work is something like the following here:

 if not instance.new_flavor.swap and instance.old_flavor.swap:
     bdms = [bdm for bdm in bdms if bdm.guest_format != 'swap']
     
And then when 'bdms' is passed to _get_instance_block_device_info() we will not get any 'swap' element in the block_device_info.

Please feel free to test that in case I've missed something. The main point is that we don't want to pass any 'swap' bdms to the _get_instance_block_device_info() method.

That aside, I think this results in the same behavior as the current code in this patch, creating a swap disk when the new flavor has swap and not creating it if the flavor has no swap, based on my testing.

It also has the same behavior of still having the 'swap' entry in the 'disk.info' file after resizing to no swap. I found that there is currently no mechanism for removing any entries from it. As you may have already found, the only code that writes this file at most can update existing entries driver format [1]. I don't know if it ever hurts anything for stale no-longer-existing entries to remain in 'disk.info' ... Maybe or probably not. But it's something that would be ideal to fix later.

And finally, this has the same behavior of not deleting any block_device_mapping DB records when going from swap to no swap. I found that similarly if you resize from no swap to swap, nova does not create a block_device_mapping DB record for the swap disk. In general, block_device_mapping DB records are never touched as a result of a resize, AFAICT.

All of this is to say, I don't think that this patch must address the 'disk.info' and block_device_mapping DB records mismatch. Only fixing the swap create vs no create behavior is the most important part and is an improvement over what we have today.

Addressing 'disk.info' and block_device_mapping records can be separate fixes and they have to consider rolling back changes if something in the resize fails after we make updates. It will take more work.

To be specific, if we have a mismatch where there is a 'swap' block_device_mapping DB record when the instance should have no swap, I think a swap disk will incorrectly be created during the instance rescue code path. (And anywhere else the LibvirtDriver._create_image() method is called).

I think this probably isn't the right way to fix this ... we generally don't want to modify block_device_info as that's generated based on the BlockDeviceMapping objects passed to _get_instance_block_device_info().

I think what's happening here is we have a BlockDeviceMapping record in the database for the swap disk, which is causing us to create a swap disk as we pass the 'bdms' variable to _get_instance_block_device_info().

We want to exclude the 'swap' block_device_mapping DB records *before* calling _get_instance_block_device_info().
Ack

I'm thinking maybe we could sync the BDM records here in the confirm resize path, that way we don't have to worry about un-deleting a BDM record during a revert. And server reboot is blocked when the instance is in the VERIFY_RESIZE state.

I ended up writing code for this because I wasn't sure it would work and I didn't want to tell you something that wouldn't work:

        # If we resized from swap to no swap or vice versa, we need to 
        # delete or create a BDM record to keep things in sync.
        # Otherwise, the instance XML will not be generated correctly
        # during a hard reboot or stop/start.
        bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid(
            context, instance.uuid)
        if not instance.new_flavor.swap and instance.old_flavor.swap:
            swap_bdms = [bdm for bdm in bdms if bdm.guest_format == 'swap']
            if swap_bdms:
                swap_bdms[0].destroy()
        elif instance.new_flavor.swap and not instance.old_flavor.swap:
             bdm_dict = block_device.create_blank_bdm(
                 instance.new_flavor.swap, 'swap')
             bdm_obj = objects.BlockDeviceMapping(
                 context, instance_uuid=instance.uuid, **bdm_dict)
             bdm_obj.update_or_create()

I put this together based on how we create BDM records during a server create [1][2][3].

I tested locally:

1. Resize from swap to no swap, confirm, then hard reboot
2. Resize from no swap to swap, confirm, then hard reboot
3. Resize from swap to no swap, revert, then hard reboot
4. Resize from no swap to swap, revert, then hard reboot

Please feel free to do further testing around it, I may have missed something. And we don't have to fix it this exact way. If you find a nicer way to handle the problem, please feel free to propose it.

I think we should also add a hard reboot to the tempest test to cover this case.

That's fair enough. I thought of resize confirm because it's the "easy" way with no rollback needed for if the user chooses to revert the resize instead of confirming it. And reboot (and other things) are blocked while the instance is in VERIFY_RESIZE state.

But, if bdms are left temporarily out of sync in general, if nova needed to regenerate the instance XML for some reason, it would not get returned to the same state it was previously in VERIFY_RESIZE. We block reboot or stop/start via vm_state, so I can't think of a "normal" way that situation could happen, off the top of my head. But things could always fail in some other unexpected way (DB errors, connection errors, etc) and if that somehow lead to us needing to regenerate the XML, it would be wrong.

Maybe we could do it in finish_resize and re-create from scratch or re-delete based on the difference from what's in the database? (This would not reuse the existing soft deleted BDM record but based on the server create code I linked earlier, that should not cause a problem.) It would also not require the addition of Instance.old_bdms/new_bdms.

Overall I agree with you and I think we just have to try/test some things to see if we can make it work without any DB changes.
Note to self: this is where we save the new flavor to instance.flavor in the database.

ya anythime your going to modify the thing your looping over make a copy.

technially unlike other lanaguages its not an error to modify the thing your loppoing on in python but its not guarteed to do what you want.

with that said in this particalyar case i would not have excpected it to cause an error as the dict comprehention on the right should have created a copy beofre the asignment happended so thos e shoudl be equivlent if the orginal value of bdms is not required.

To be clear, it didn't cause any error ... what happened was when I was trying stuff I initially tried syncing the bdm records in finish_resize above. And to do that, I needed the original list of bdms that did not exclude the swap disk. But since 'bdms' had been overwritten, I no longer had the original list available.

That made me think in general, even if it doesn't cause an error now, probably best not to do it anyway... the next developer might get thrown off by it if they needed to add some handling of the bdms later on.

Something else I noticed while testing is that even after I started syncing the DB records (and thus the bdms here) I didn't get a wrong result going from no swap to swap (and not adding a new BDM until after resize confirm) ...

I found it's because in some places, the driver is looking only at the *flavor* to make decisions about swap [1]. So even though we don't pass a swap BDM, our swap disk gets created anyway if the flavor has it.

When I realized this, I wondered if we should do something in the driver to remove swap based on the flavor only ... but according to a code comment [2], using the flavor for this is not ideal and that we should be going toward using only BDMs for dealing with swap. I think adding more flavor code in the driver might add debt, so I'm thinking maybe a simple approach with the BDMs is better for now. If anyone disagrees, please add a comment.

Moving everything to BDM-only in the future will be its own refactoring project.

nova.tests.functional.test_servers.ServerMovingTests.test_resize_swap_expand_to_non_zero [7.748597s] ... ok
nova.tests.functional.test_servers.ServerMovingTests.test_resize_swap_shrink_to_non_zero [8.186368s] ... ok

Off the top of my head I don't know if there is any way we could reproduce the buggy behavior in the tests such that they would protect against regression.
I realized I think we could do this by verifying the state of the instance block device mappings before/after resize. That way the test would fail without the fix and pass with the fix.

At the beginning of the test you can do:

 self.api.microversion = '2.47'

so that you'll call the nova API with a later microversion (default is the lowest, 2.1) because instance flavor embedded details that you want to assert on were added in microversion 2.47 [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#id43

Before creating the server, you can create a flavor [1] with swap (I'm copying the values you had added to the flavors fixture but you can omit/change whatever you need):

 flavor = self._create_flavor(
     name='m1.small.swap1',
     memory_mb=2048,
     vcpus=1,
     disk=20,
     ephemeral=0,
     swap=1024,
 )
 
[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/a2964417822bd1a4a83fa5c27282d2be1e18868a/nova/tests/functional/integrated_helpers.py#L369

Then you can pass it here:

 server = self._create_server(flavor_id=flavor['id'], networks=[])

I think we should also verify the block device mapping records as they are separate from the instance.flavor. Maybe something like this:

        # verify block device mapping
        ctxt = context.get_admin_context()
        bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid(
            ctxt, server['id'])
        self.assertIn('swap', [bdm.guest_format for bdm in bdms])

And then:

        # verify no swap in block device mapping
        bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid(
            ctxt, server['id'])
        self.assertNotIn('swap', [bdm.guest_format for bdm in bdms])

Similar thing here:

 flavor1 = self._create_flavor(
     name='m1.small.swap1',
     memory_mb=2048,
     vcpus=1,
     disk=20,
     ephemeral=0,
     swap=1024,
 )
 flavor2 = self._create_flavor(
     name='m1.small.swap1',
     memory_mb=2048,
     vcpus=1,
     disk=20,
     ephemeral=0,
     swap=2048,
 )

Would be good to also verify the block device mapping:

        # verify block device mapping
        ctxt = context.get_admin_context()
        bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid(
            ctxt, server['id'])
        swap_bdms = [bdm for bdm in bdms if bdm.guest_format == 'swap']
        self.assertEqual(1, len(swap_bdms))
        self.assertEqual(2048, swap_bdms[0].volume_size)

flavor = self._create_flavor(
     name='m1.small.swap1',
     memory_mb=2048,

     ephemeral=0,

sushy_tools/emulator/resources/systems/l.message: outside of ironic, okay, but if this is happening with Ironic, that would seem like a bug.

I have reproduced this only outside of the ironic. But this is something interesting as redfish spec does allow setonce, while there is no such option in the libvirt. And there is no queue or state keeper in sushy-tools. You can just set what it should be and that is all. There is no option to set it for one boot. And it can be really tricky to find that the server was rebooted if this wasn't triggered through sushy-tools. So that is the reason for the "hacky way" I've proposed.

nova/cmd/common.py.message:
I think I was too cavalier in my explanations on internal Slack. What I would do is to use the contextlib library [1] to write a new context manager. There are a few examples in the existing Nova code, the most useful for you is probably mutated_migration_context. I've left comments so that you can see where it's defined and how it's used. The basic idea is:

1. Do some stuff - in your case it would be locking the instance.
2. try/yield - enter what's inside the `with` block when the context manager is called
3. finally - do some more stuff, regardless of any exceptions thrown inside the `with` block. In your case, it would be unlocking the instance if necessary.

Hope that helps!

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/contextlib.html

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This looks a little insane, on two counts. I'm not even putting -1 to this, I must be not reading it in right frame of mind.
1. Flopping timeouts on every read? Really?
2. The parameter's name is keepalive but its action is timeout. In normal circumstances, keepalive is smaller than timeout, so that it can forestall the timeout. It's a gotcha you're embedding.

It *is* a little insane -- probably better as an eventlet patch: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/pull/788

But:

- Timeouts are only getting flopped every time we read *a request line* -- and that's for the sake of eventlet, anyway -- the actual low-level socket object will stay nonblocking this whole time.
- I'm thinking "keepalive" in the HTTP sense, rather than TCP sense. It was an unfortunate conflation of ideas :-( `idle_timeout` would probably be better...

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: recheck centos8 jobs timed out, appears to have been working but didn't reach the last step before timing out.

FWIW the only one of these that seemed to help us drop idle sockets faster was wsgi_keepalive = False (which effectively disables http 1.1 connection: keep-alive and pipeline requests) so every socket is closed after a single response.

I do like plumbing these through, just some thoughts inline. We're missing the keepalive interval option, which defaults (in linux) to 75 seconds, which we'd also want configurable.

I also tested this on a known recreated issue, which deals with stale/idle connections from a bad client. By it self the job takes 15 minutes, but:

client_timeout = 1.0

real    0m26.439s
user    0m1.088s
sys     0m0.517s


wsgi_keepalive = false

real    0m10.810s
user    0m1.084s
sys     0m0.626s

So I think it's nice to have these options.

It's nice having these exposed. Spending the end of last week debugging and tracking down issues that could have been "resolved" or at least used an option here as a work around just make it more flexible!

I was planning on whipping something like this up today, but nice to see it already done as I come in on Monday morning, thanks Clay!

I'm going to give this a whirl in my test env where I was experiencing an issue that this would solve, if all goes well will give it my +2.

NP, I can respin.

You noted that it would be useful (with the problem we're having in prod, right now) if ops had the option to configure wsgi_keepalive=False (which currently, ops can not).  I think I saw you also concluded that there may be value in configuring the tcp keepalive settings (which currently, ops can not) - do I have that right?

Moreover I think you're saying this patch is DEFICIENT (-1).  i.e. it is not complete, it doesn't make swift *only* better.  And I think the reason you gave is because it's missing 1/3 values needed to FULLY configure tcp keepalive (which currently swift does not support, but half-assed support is worse than none).  So you'd like me to EXPAND the patch?  I want to confirm, you think the BEST way to change THIS patch would be to add a NEW configuration (N.B. this patch makes 3 hard-coded settings configurable already).

What would you think about pulling out the tcp keepalive configuration from this patch - just leave them hard-coded - maybe tcp keepalive is unrelated/useless?  Maybe it'd be easier for us to agree on a diff that is complete and makes swift better if the change only did *ONE* thing: add support to configure wsgi_keepalive=False

Then if we have a reason to support tcp keepalive configuration in the future we could add that in too!  What do you think?

i think working on the eventlet/wsgi guts to identify idle sockets between requests, so that we can limit the # of idle connections, how long we keep an idle connection between requests, and what to do with idle connections when the accept queue has a new connection but the handler pool is full .. . would all be useful things to pursue as well.

Yeah I'm trying to be more honest - I appreciate your feedback.

Thanks for checking my thinking before I spun another patch - let me know if you think we need to make this new slimmer version better still, or if perhaps it's just not useful to give ops this knob?

If we want to work on tcp keepalive tuning in the future we can pick up https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/873942

OK, that is an interesting response :)

Yeah, so the patch as it stands is making swift better, but also allowing ops to control the tcp keep alive settings, both I think are great, except the tcp keep alive settings are only 2/3 complete, so the patch makes swift better, but also incomplete, as it can't really configure tcp keep alive (thus the -1).

If you want want to split into 2, cool, or yes add a new keepalive_intvl config option so we can fully configure the proxies keepalive settings.

Maybe we're not using the keepalive features too much today, but I do wonder if they might be useful, so I for one wouldn't mind playing around with them. If we have them easily configurable that would make it easier.

TL;DR: respin as either 2 patches (and we'll land the first now) or as one and add an interval. I don't mind which. Until there is in a release for us downstream we're not going to make use the to wsgi_keepalive=false. So either way.

<keepalive tangent>
The keepalive defaults might not be super useful for us, but if we tune them down, we could have some extra connection monitoring on our connections that could disconnect before we hard fail on a client_idle (which ends up basically being a blocking timeout). So we can have a hardline idle timeout of a connection AND potentially have keep alive do a ligher check for connectivity probe. And at the code of an empty packet or a few getting more socket connection garbage collection, might be worth it.
</tangent>

etc/proxy-server.conf-sample.message: turning this down to 1.0 also has the effect of kicking idle connections off the eventlet.wsgi pool - but effects all operations on the socket in general, not just between requests.
Should we add a little bit extra in the comment to say something like, "max time in seconds before requiring a keepalive packet" or do we just expect people will lookup what TCP_KEEPIDLE means?

setting max_http_version to 'HTTP/1.0' also solved the problem in the wsgi server object, basically does the same thing as keepalive = false. So keepalive = false is better. But changing it to max_http_version to 1.0 is the first thing I did last week in my test enviornment which then "solved" the issue (or rather was going to be a possible workaround) until the eventlet patch merged. But yeah, then I saw the keepalive option, which did the same thing, basically.

If we're going to support keep alive configuration, we're missing a major option.

Keepalive has 3 options:

  - socket.TCP_KEEPIDLE (send first keep alive after being idle this long, we have this one)
  - socket.TCP_KEEPINTVL (after the first keep alive is fired how ofter to keep sending them, we don't have this one)
  - socket.TCP_KEEPCNT (how many keep alives need to fail before we drop the connection, we have this one too).
 
So we're missing the keepalive interval (keepintvl). The default under linux for the interval is 75, so we may want to change that.

The client_timeout seems to set the established socket timeout. So a timeout on blocking connections. So not sure a keepalive probe response would be considered data, so not sure client_timeout and tcp_keepalive will work well together, unless the keepalives are tiny.

I wonder if we'd rely on keep alives more, say client_timeout = 0 (turn off) and keep_idle = 10, keep_interval = 10, keep_cnt = 6. Would do something similar. But I it wouldn't do a hard drop.

Maybe client_timeout = 60, keep_idle = 2, keep_interval = 2, keep_cnt = 5

which would give us a hard timeout, but also detect a stale connection faster.

Might have to have a play with a bunch of settings.
Should we also a bit more in the comment here saying something like, "number of unacked keepalive probes before dropping the connection" ?

swift/common/wsgi.py.message: I don't love it -- keepalive True/False seems like such a blunt instrument -- I think we can use the truthiness test in existing eventlet to smuggle in another timeout: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/873744

Hi Luis,

Thank you for taking this on.

I did not check all of the commit IDs in the YAML files, but my understanding is that you picked the commits that introduced the drivers in question to set the base commit ID.

Were you able to confirm whether the package versions (or releases) produced with this commit are greater than the versions/releases that existed prior to this commit?

etc/proxy-server.conf-sample.message: Does this setting need to be the same on every proxy node? E.g. can it be that one acquires the token at proxy A with Tempauth, then talks to proxy B, sends the token, and then what?

Point taken -- I'll look at switching to something like we do for encryption; see https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.31.0/etc/proxy-server.conf-sample#L1232-L1243

In short, allow multiple `fernet_key_<key_id>` config options, any of which can be used to decrypt, and a `active_fernet_key_id = <key_id>` to specify which one to use for new encryptions. If blank or omitted, use the old-style tokens -- this is a little different from what we do for encryption, but I think we *would've* done this if we'd been thinking more about key rotation from the start.

Config change then looks like:

- Push out `fernet_key_2023_02 = ...` (say) to nodes one by one, restarting proxies as you go. When done, everyone can read such tokens, but no one is writing them.
- Push out `active_fernet_key_id = 2023_02` to nodes one by one, restarting proxies as you go. Everyone gradually flops over to issuing fernet tokens.

This also supports key rotation; next month, you'd:

- Push out `fernet_key_2023_03 = ...`
- Push out `active_fernet_key_id = 2023_03`
- Wait for all old tokens to have expired
- Push out a config to remove `fernet_key_2023_02`
Yes, the secret would need to be shared across all proxies. I'll add that to the description above.

Very well, but what if you are in the process of upgrading the cluster, and then you change this configuration and restart nodes one by one? Is there a requirement to maneuver at LB level?

For example. Suppose you have 4 proxies: A...D. Reconfigure LB to exclude A,B. Shut down A,B. Change config to Fernet. Boot A,B. Switch LB to A,B, exclude C,D. At this point, old-style tokens, issued by C,D will be verified by A,B. But tokens issued by A,B will be Fernet ones. Now you can change LB back to allow all of A...B. Is this how this is supposed to be handled?

templates/collect_logs.yaml.j2.message:
This work and enable the double escaping.

    - name: get podman container state at this stage
      vars:
        f_open: '{% raw %}{{"{{"}}{% endraw %}'
        f_close: '{% raw %}{{"}}"}}{% endraw %}'
      shell: |
        sudo podman ps  --format {% raw %}"{{ f_open }}.Names{{ f_close }} {{ f_open }}.ID{{ f_close }} {{ f_open }}.Image{{ f_close }}"{% endraw %} | sort &>> /var/log/extra/container-ps-{% raw %}{{ current_stage }}{% endraw %}.txt

This can be container-ps-before_oc_update_run.txt only when all roles
are run in parallel.

If there are run serially, then we will get
container-ps-before_oc_update_run-<role name>.txt and the check will fail.

Here's a way to make it work as expected:

    - name: Get all logs files related to container.
      find:
        paths: "/var/log/extra/"
        patterns: 'container-ps-before_oc_update_run*.txt'
      register: found_files

    - name: Get the latest file related to container
      set_fact:
        latest_log: "{% raw %}{{ found_files.files | sort(attribute='mtime',reverse=true) | first }}{% endraw %}"

    - name: check if podman images are updated
      command: "comm -12 /var/log/extra/container-ps-before_reboot.txt {% raw %}{{ latest_log.path }}{% endraw %}"
      register: comm_result
      when: "current_stage == 'before_reboot'"

You have to remove the {{ }} around current_stage as it's a variable
in a conditional. The *raw/endraw* can go as well.

    when: " current_stage == 'before_reboot'"
    
is working here.

We need to grep out container that are expected to not be updated at
certain steps.

Oki, I see, if we run in tripleo_ci then we don't do the test as
container are not updated.

I'd rather had a specific parameter like "tripleo_upgrade_run_tests"
and have it set to false by default as it will enable easy integration
with infrared.

Something to keep in mind for the next refactor, not a blocker.

I don't like that it doesn't have a default value here (undefined
means false I guess)

Hum, so on the line above it's a variable during the job meaning we
could pass a diffirent container_check_exclude for each stage. But on
this line it's directly rendered.

We need to settle on direct render or a job parameter, ie either "raw"
for both or for none (which currently would work as well as we only
have one stage of exclude container.)
Sorry, I did a confusion: when is not a jinja template and as such we don't need a raw there.

cinder/api/v3/volumes.py.message: pep8: E501 line too long (81 > 79 characters)
Please, add unit-tests for this change to prevent the issue in the future
We've made an effort to avoid using \ to span multiple lines because it can cause subtle bugs. Please wrap the conditions for the if statement in () so it can span lines without using \.
This doesn't take into account negative time offsets.

This block especially handles for "+", since "2020-07-06 04:41:57.768583+08:00" will be "2020-07-06 04:41:57.768583 08:00" when Cinder API get the request parameter string, this format "2020-07-06 04:41:57.768583 08:00" can't be parsed to iso time so that why we need to transfer it in here. But it's no change to "-", so "2020-07-06 04:41:57.768583-08:00" still be the same format when Cinder API gets it. So it could be parsed as normal. we didn't need to handle negative time offsets here.

cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: This is because I found if the user specifies the time comparison operators like: "updated_at=lt:time1,gt:time2", it should mean "time2 < volume.updated_time < time1", so there should be 'and' not 'or' relationship with those two operators.

the test is "test_quota_copy_from ... no_src"

but this test *does* have an x-copy-from src, and a register call to make the GET work - why does the PUT fail with "payload too large" if quota 'never seen sees the PUT"

The *old* behavior was terrible, too -- looking at FakeApp, you want to think there's a 404, but there *isn't*! `copy` doesn't issue a HEAD, only a GET, so there was a zero-byte 200 -- i.e. there *was* a src.

If we *did* issue a 404... we would no longer be testing the quota middleware, only copy! I'm not opposed to renaming the test, but at least it's (1) testing account quotas and (2) hitting an otherwise not-covered path.

Since, with real HW iscsi shall not be needed.

Created a separate review for the inclusion of open-iscsi: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/tools/+/862708

Also created a task to revert the inclusion of open-iscsi after the HW tests are completed: Story:2010046/Task:46660

Two choices as I see it:
- Support TrueNAS in StarlingX 8.0 as a multipath solution used for virtual development. Then this goes in as-is
- Don't support TrueNAS in StarlingX 8.0 as a multipath solution. The open-iscsi package then needs to go in as a separate commit (so can easily be reverted prior to release of StarlingX 8.0). Add a task to story 2010046 to revert the partial TrueNAS support code (and we revert the commit prior to release).

My preference would be to have a supported solution that we can use for virtual development. I'm just not sure how far away we are from making that happen.

I think option 2 is better since we don't have yet a full support on multipath with TrueNAS on the kickstart. This is still not a full multipath virtualized support since requires all the iscsi configuration to be integrated at installer/kickstart. The focus on the scope of this change is to prepare the kickstart to be tested in the real HW using firmware-qlogic.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I assume there is or will be instructions in the documentation for users to generate their own key pairs.

I really don't like having the keys, even public keys, mixed in with the code.

I would prefer to have a mechanism where the signing server can be asked to provide the public key.  

An alternative design might be to provide keys via an independent 'public-keys' git mounted at cgcs-root/stx/public-keys.   e.g. cgcs-root/stx/public-keys/secure-boot/boot_pub.key
Removing my +1 until Scott is satisfied.

If the users want to generate their own key, they need recompile the grub-efi package and iso image and redo the whole secure boot signing process again. This key is of the same importance with tis-shim/tis-boot. Will this be a user case? 
Thanks.

Please refer to /cgcs-root/stx/integ/security/shim-unsigned/files/tis-shim.crt, and we can see that centos stx use this way too. If we want to improve it on debian stx,
I prefer to use your alternative design suggestion. I have some question about it:
Where should this 'public-keys' git be put at upstream?
I should put all the pub keys include tis-boot/tis-shim/boot_pub_key there because they form the secure boot signing verification. Right?
Thanks.

Please refer to the details of my answers in my email replied.

Because the 3 commits (868918/868919/868920 and maybe more now) I have sent upstream and a coming commit (change to lat-sdk.sh) work together to set up a new auto signing process for remote signing server, which isn't quite bundled with this pub key enhancement for functions, can we divide them into 2 stories? This can make function changes clearer.

How about that I create a new story for this enhancement and work on it immediately after above commits finished?  Thanks.

I agree that all public keys, tis-boot/tis-shim/boot_pub_key, should be relocated to the proposed public-keys git.

This was a project that I had intended to undertake for CentOS for some time now.  Now that we are planning to abandoning CentOS, it's probably not worth fixing for that OS.

I can assist in creating the new git, but perhaps you'll need a bit of time to verify that the proposed design can be made to work?
I'm still looking for those keys to be moved to an separate git
Rebase the patch for grub-efi related packages' installations should be moved to debian_iso_image.inc now.
